ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Skills in editing colors of digital photography through PhotoShop and photography theory in general
I learned an incredible amount about photography as an art form and about the technical process of taking good photographs.
Basic photography and photoshop knowledge
I learned how to operate a digital camera, edit digital photos in color in Photoshop, and print digital photos.
How to do photoshop and take photos
how to adjust exposure and take photos, upload and organize/save files, color correcting and other edits with bridge, lightroom, and photoshope

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strength: general skills of photography editing and taking, not too much work and pretty enjoyable 
Weakness: is not super intense or rigorous if you are looking for an advanced photography course

This is an incredible course. It gives agency to the students to decide how they want to interpret the medium of photography. It is somehow both loosely structured and incredibly rigorous. I do wish that the first couple of weeks were a bit more structured, however. I would have liked more specific photography assignments (i.e. take a photo of a person), so that we could slowly develop our own photography practice throughout the semester. I also would have liked even more instruction on the history of photography and on past and contemporary titans of the art form.
More critiques! But I appreciated the time spent learning photoshop
I loved the critiques, guest lecturers, and seeing other photographers' work. I didn't enjoy our workdays in Photoshop as much and I felt they were paced slowly.
Was a super fun course wish we went out to take photos more in class

I liked how exploratory it was -- ted just wants you to fall in love with photography which is amazing -- and part of it is just doing it yourself and learning through experience and we definitely were given the freedom and opportunity to practice. one thing I wished we did was more crits because that's when we got to see each others work and get feedback, it was very intimidating to just be given unlimited freedom so I wish we got more opportunity for discussion and structured help. don't know if this is possible but I loved how we learned and looked at so many other photographers, and wish we had mini workshops or something in which we tried to emulate a style of a photographer we talked about that week or so and learn that way
Enjoyed the course but I think it could have done with a bit more structure: we had few if any lectures about technical aspects like perspective/composition.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! It's pretty chill and enjoyable

Absolutely. This course changed the way that I think about the world and made me realize that I am a lot more artistic than I previously thought. I grew in so many ways and now feel like photography will be a part of my life forever. If I had taken this course freshman year I might have decided to be an art major.
Yep! Fun for all levels

Yes if you are brand new to photography! However, if you're looking for a very engaging hands-on course I would suggest a film photography class instead. You very much have to motivate yourself to put in the work for this class to get something out of it because it's so relaxed.
Yes it is such a great course
YES IF YOU CAN GET INTO THIS CLASS TAKE IT YOU WON'T REGRET IT ONE OF THE BEST CLASSES AT YALE
I would and have. Very enjoyable and a good experiment even for non-art majors.
